seo.title: Graphical Analysis Quiz – Trends, S/R, Patterns & Candlesticks | Qption

seo.keywords: graphical analysis quiz, technical analysis quiz, chart patterns, support and resistance, Fibonacci, Elliott Waves, head and shoulders, flags, pennants, trend continuation, reversals, Qption
seo.ogTitle: Graphical Analysis Quiz – Trends, S/R, Patterns & Candlesticks | Qption
seo.ogDescription: Challenge yourself with interactive questions on trends, S/R, Fibonacci & Elliott, and continuation/reversal patterns.
seo.twitterDescription: Put your chart skills to the test with Qption’s Graphical Analysis Quiz.

page.title: Graphical Analysis
page.subtitle: Challenge your chart-reading skills with our interactive Graphical Analysis Quiz — test your understanding of trend lines, support/resistance, Fibonacci & Elliott concepts, and continuation/reversal patterns to become a more confident, visually-driven trader.

quiz.selectHint: Select an option and submit your answer.

tier.good: Nice work! Keep practicing to level up.
tier.retry: Good start—review the lessons and try again.

pool.q: In graphical analysis, a rising moving average most often suggests:
pool.explain: Slope and price position relative to the MA help define directional bias at a glance.

pool.q: A common way to use moving averages as dynamic S/R is to:
options: Wait for price to ignore them
Look for pullbacks to the MA in trend for continuation
Fade every MA touch regardless of context
pool.correct: Look for pullbacks to the MA in trend for continuation
pool.explain: Pullbacks to MAs during trends can offer structure for risk placement and continuation entries.

pool.q: Compared to an SMA, an EMA is typically:
pool.explain: EMAs weight recent data more, turning quicker than SMAs—useful for faster trend cues.

pool.q: A basic bullish crossover cue occurs when:
options: Longer MA crosses above shorter MA
Shorter MA crosses above longer MA
pool.correct: Shorter MA crosses above longer MA
pool.explain: Short-over-long crossovers can highlight momentum shifts (still lagging—seek confluence).

pool.q: A widely watched retracement cluster for pullbacks is:
pool.explain: These Fibonacci zones are popular for identifying potential reaction areas within trends.

options: Multiple Fib levels/structures aligning in the same area
pool.correct: Multiple Fib levels/structures aligning in the same area
pool.explain: Confluence (e.g., 61.8% + prior S/R + MA) strengthens the significance of a zone.

pool.q: In a classic Elliott impulse, the wave count is typically:
pool.explain: Standard structure: five waves with the trend (1–5) followed by ABC correction.

pool.q: A common Elliott guideline is that in an impulse:
options: Wave 4 commonly overlaps wave 1 in standard impulses
Wave 3 is often the longest (not the shortest)
Waves must be equal in time
pool.correct: Wave 3 is often the longest (not the shortest)
pool.explain: Wave 3 frequently carries strongest momentum and should not be the shortest among 1,3,5.

pool.q: A Head & Shoulders top typically confirms when:
options: Price breaks the neckline with acceptance
Volume decreases on the left shoulder
pool.correct: Price breaks the neckline with acceptance
pool.explain: Neckline breaks (ideally with volume/confirmation) validate the reversal structure.

pool.q: Double bottoms are more reliable when:
options: They form in strong uptrends only
They’re accompanied by bullish divergence or strong reclaim
They occur without any prior down move
pool.correct: They’re accompanied by bullish divergence or strong reclaim
pool.explain: Momentum confirmation or structure reclaim strengthens reversal probability.

pool.q: A bearish reversal clue at resistance can be:
pool.explain: Wedges near resistance that break down can precede deeper pullbacks or trend shifts.

pool.q: Flags and pennants are usually considered:
pool.explain: Brief consolidations that typically resolve in the direction of the prior impulse.

options: Up, as buyers press a horizontal ceiling
pool.correct: Up, as buyers press a horizontal ceiling
pool.explain: Higher lows into flat resistance suggest building pressure for an upward break (confirmation needed).
Ranges are neutral containers; context, volume, and breakout behavior guide bias.

pool.q: A ‘measured move’ target for a flag/pennant is often estimated by:
options: Prior impulse height projected from the breakout
pool.correct: Prior impulse height projected from the breakout
pool.explain: The pole height is often projected from the breakout point as a pragmatic first target.

options: Visual structures like trends, S/R, patterns, and levels
pool.correct: Visual structures like trends, S/R, patterns, and levels
pool.explain: It prioritizes chart structure, context, and price behavior to guide decisions.

pool.q: A best practice is to align entries with:
options: Higher timeframe trend and key levels
pool.correct: Higher timeframe trend and key levels
pool.explain: Top-down confluence improves probabilities and clarity for execution.

pool.q: Which helps reduce false breakouts in patterns?
options: Entering on first tick through the level always
Waiting for close/acceptance beyond level and/or retest
pool.correct: Waiting for close/acceptance beyond level and/or retest
pool.explain: Confirmed breaks and retests provide stronger evidence than intrabar pokes.

options: Beyond invalidation structure (e.g., above/below pattern extremes)
pool.correct: Beyond invalidation structure (e.g., above/below pattern extremes)
pool.explain: Structure-based stops define risk and clarify when the idea is wrong.
